Award.AwardTitle: Processing of Advanced Foam Scaffolds for Iron-Air Battery Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The generation, storage, and local use of hydrogen to generate electric power via fuel cells are critical to reaching an electrical grid with low-to-zero carbon dioxide emissions, benefiting the U.S. economy and worldwide society. In recent years, iron oxide powder has attracted attention as an inexpensive, non-toxic option to store and create pure hydrogen through the iron-oxide reduction/oxidation ("redox") reaction. One of the main problems associated with this cyclical redox reaction is powder pulverization and subsequent agglomeration and consolidation. These effects drastically reduce the high surface areas needed for the reaction. Thus, maintaining stability, high surface area and high gas permeability in the powder bed after multiple redox cycles are the main challenges for this promising technology. This award supports research to develop a structure that takes advantage of novel processing approaches to create iron scaffolds which can maintain structural integrity, high permeability and high surface area during the redox cycles, thus enabling a novel, inexpensive and non-toxic iron-air battery for large scale use.

In this research program, the investigators will directionally freeze an aqueous suspension of iron oxide nanopowders to create ice dendrites, which will push the particles into interdendritic space, thus creating a network of iron oxide powders walls. After hydrogen reduction, this network is sintered into a continuous scaffold with directionally aligned channels templating the original ice dendrites, surrounded by iron walls with high surface area and enough internal free space to achieve the microstructural stability needed to withstand multiple reduction/oxidation cycles without sintering or pulverization. The scaffold stability will be further improved by adding various materials to the iron oxide nanopowder suspension: (i) nickel oxide powders which are co-reduced to form iron-nickel solid solution walls with higher strength; (ii) space-holder powders such as strontium fluoride, which can be evaporated from the scaffold walls to generate further porosity within the walls and increase their surface area and the free volume to accommodate volume changes and (iii) inert reinforcements such as ceramic particles, which will strengthen and stiffen the scaffold walls. Mechanical testing will be used to examine relative structural degradation of samples after reduction/oxidation cycles, and x-ray tomography and finite element modeling will be used to map and examine 3-dimensional scaffold structure and stress distribution within its walls during the volumetric changes associated with the redox cycles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Renewable electricity generation, like wind and solar power, will help us address climate change and improve our energy security, at rates that are highly competitive with coal or gas-produced electricity. But, since the sun and the wind are not always on, we need a way to store up extra electricity during times of overproduction, so we can use it for cloudy or windless days. This will require a huge scale of energy storage, and one option to do it is with iron-based batteries. Iron is cheap, abundant, and non-toxic, unless many materials used in current batteries. The problem with these iron batteries is that, when they are cycled, the iron materials degrades: every charge and discharge causes the iron to double in size and then shrink again, and these repeated volume changes cause the iron to deform and agglomerate, which slows down the chemical reactions needed to make the battery work.

In this project, we demonstrated a new way of creating iron battery materials designed to withstand those large volume changes, so they don?t degrade as quickly. We use a method called freeze casting to create porous ?sponges? of iron, which have enough open space in their structure to accommodate large volume changes without collapsing. In freeze casting, iron oxide (rust, literally) is mixed with water to form a suspension. This suspension is put in a tube and frozen from one end to the other, and as it freezes ice crystals grow like snowflakes inside the tube, all aligned in the freezing direction. The rust particles get pushed into the spaces between ice crystals, resulting in a stack of alternating rust and ice layers. The next step is freeze drying, which sublimates the ice and leaves a lamellar structure of thin iron oxide walls with open spaces where the ice was. Finally, this foam is heated under hydrogen gas to turn the rust into metallic iron, leaving an iron foam that can be used for the batteries.

We tested these foams to see what would happen during battery cycling. They worked, but we still wanted to see how their foam structure was changing. We used X-ray computed tomography (CT) to image the 3-dimensional foam, much like a medical doctor uses a CT scan to take images inside a human body. With tomography, we observed the ?breathing? of the iron foams as they expanded and contracted during cycling, and from these images we discovered the fundamental mechanisms causing their degradation. We found that the foam?s design provided enough open space for the discharging (volume expansion) step, but during charge the structure did not return to its original shape. An imbalance in how quickly iron and oxygen diffused through the material ? a process called the Kirkendall effect ? was creating new micropores in the iron, which weakened the structure and made deformation more likely.

Equipped with these new insights, we made changes to the foam composition in ways we predicted would address the Kirkendall effect. We adapted the freeze casting process to incorporate either a ceramic material, like yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ), or an alloying material, like nickel. We tested iron-YSZ and iron-nickel foams, both of which showed improved structural stability. Iron-nickel foams containing 25 at. % Ni demonstrated a very robust structure, with over 10 times less degradation[SKW1]  compared to the original iron foams. By analyzing foams after the first discharge, recharge, and after several cycles, we discovered that the nickel addition results in a ductile, nickel-rich skeleton that connects throughout the foam structure and mechanically stabilizes it, and fewer Kirkendall micropores were observed.

Broader Impacts

            This work has supported the educational and professional development of many students, including one Ph.D. student and 2 undergraduate students. Additionally, we hosted 2 visiting graduate students from international collaborators at Kookmin University (South Korea) and Seville University (Spain), which helped advance the techniques for freeze casting, battery cycling, and 3D analysis of tomography data.

            This project has also enabled numerous STEM outreach efforts at Northwestern University and the surrounding community. These have included organizing a STEM problem-solving competition for 60 local middle-school students, leading a short course on dye-sensitized solar cells for high-school students, and giving topical science presentations to residents at local retirement communities.
